questions.question: A 4-year-old child is exhibiting 'food jag' behavior. According to the portion size guidelines in Lesson 1, what is the standard recommended serving size for a single food group (like cooked vegetables) for this child?
options: 1/2 cup
4 tablespoons (1 tablespoon per year of age)
1 cup
6 tablespoons
questions.explanation: The 'Rule of Thumb' for preschooler portion sizes is approximately 1 tablespoon of each food group per year of age. For a 4-year-old, this equals 4 tablespoons.

questions.question: Which long-chain omega-3 fatty acid is most critical for supporting the structural integrity of the brain and improving focus and cognitive performance in school-age children?
options: Alpha-linolenic acid (ALA)
Oleic acid
Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA)
Linoleic acid
questions.explanation: DHA is a primary structural component of the human brain and retina. Studies show that adequate DHA levels are linked to better concentration and memory in school-aged children.

questions.question: To effectively combat the 'after-school slump' and prevent reactive hypoglycemia, a snack should ideally combine which two components?
options: Fiber-rich carbohydrates and lean protein/healthy fats
Simple sugars and caffeine
High-sodium processed grains and fruit juice
Water and a vitamin supplement
questions.explanation: Combining fiber-rich carbohydrates with protein or fats slows digestion and the release of glucose into the bloodstream, providing stable energy rather than a spike and crash.

questions.question: For a 10-year-old child athlete participating in a 60-minute vigorous sports activity, what is the recommended hydration protocol to prevent performance-limiting dehydration?
options: Drinking only when the child reports feeling thirsty
Consumption of 500ml of a caffeinated energy drink before the game
150-250ml of water every 20 minutes during activity
2 liters of water immediately after the activity ends
questions.explanation: Children have a higher surface-area-to-body-mass ratio and are more susceptible to heat. Periodic hydration (150-250ml every 20 mins) is safer and more effective than waiting for thirst.

questions.question: When using CDC growth charts to assess a child's weight status, a BMI-for-age percentile between the 85th and 95th percentile is categorized as:
options: Healthy weight
Overweight
Obese
Severely Obese
questions.explanation: The CDC defines 'Overweight' as a BMI at or above the 85th percentile and below the 95th percentile for children of the same age and sex.

questions.question: Regarding dental health, which factor is more detrimental to tooth enamel than the total amount of sugar consumed?
options: The type of toothbrush used
The frequency of exposure to fermentable carbohydrates
The temperature of the food
The time of day the sugar is consumed
questions.explanation: Frequent snacking on fermentable carbohydrates keeps the mouth's pH low (acidic) for longer periods, preventing remineralization and increasing the risk of dental caries.

questions.question: According to the 'Forbidden Fruit' effect discussed in Lesson 8, what is a common psychological outcome of strictly prohibiting 'junk' foods?
options: The child loses all interest in the prohibited food
The child develops a natural preference for leafy greens
Increased obsession and overconsumption of the food when access is eventually gained
A permanent increase in the child's metabolic rate
questions.explanation: Research shows that restrictive feeding practices often backfire, leading to increased 'eating in the absence of hunger' and a fixation on the restricted items.

questions.question: A 7-year-old child is frequently irritable and unable to focus on homework at 4:00 PM. Which 'bridge snack' would best support their metabolic needs?
options: A bowl of sugary cereal with skim milk
A handful of gummy fruit snacks
Hummus with carrot sticks and whole-grain pita
A sports drink and a bag of potato chips
questions.explanation: Hummus (protein/fat) and carrots/pita (fiber/complex carbs) provide the necessary nutrient density to stabilize blood sugar and support cognitive function.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key strategy for addressing childhood obesity with compassion, as outlined in Lesson 6?
options: Focusing exclusively on weight and BMI numbers during family discussions
Implementing a strict 'no-sugar' policy for the child only
Shifting the focus from weight to health-promoting behaviors for the whole family
Encouraging the child to exercise as a punishment for overeating
questions.explanation: A weight-neutral, health-behavior-focused approach reduces stigma and promotes sustainable lifestyle changes without damaging the child's self-esteem.

questions.question: For optimal muscle recovery and glycogen replenishment after a competitive sports event, when should a child consume a recovery snack containing both carbohydrates and protein?
options: Within 30-60 minutes post-exercise
At least 4 hours after the event
Only the following morning
Immediately before going to sleep
questions.explanation: The 'metabolic window' for glycogen synthesis is most active immediately following exercise. Consuming a 3:1 or 4:1 carb-to-protein ratio within 30-60 minutes optimizes recovery.
